# But Will Associates In The Mutara Nebula Get A Cut Of These Raises?
## Or does 'all U.S. offices' also cover associates who bring high-end legal representation to the Crab People?
By [Elie Mystal](https://abovethelaw.com/author/elie-mystal/)  
onJune 26, 2018 at 5:30 PMJune 28, 2018 at 1:32 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/but-will-associates-in-the-mutara-nebula-get-a-cut-of-these-raises/&text=But%20Will%20Associates%20In%20The%20Mutara%20Nebula%20Get%20A%20Cut%20Of%20These%20Raises?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/but-will-associates-in-the-mutara-nebula-get-a-cut-of-these-raises/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/but-will-associates-in-the-mutara-nebula-get-a-cut-of-these-raises/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
DLA Piper, which once listed that it [had an office in “country” of Africa](https://abovethelaw.com/2013/02/dla-piper-literally-doesnt-know-what-country-some-of-their-offices-are-in/), has entered the associate raise game.

It’s a straight match of Cravath, for all U.S. offices in major markets. DLA Piper is famously large, with offices all over the world. Matching the associate raises is big news for the market, just because of the sheer size of the firm. Now, anytime Reed Smith or Greenberg Traurig make you a job offer, know that there’s a DLA Piper office, probably inside the local bus station, willing to pay you more money than those firms.

Here’s the memo. It… really is this short (no summer bonuses). And I’d like to think that the scribbling was included in the original, but that’s probably just tipster flair.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  


As you can see, DLA offers free helium to all those who work in the U.S.

I don’t know how the U.S. raises will play with associates just outside the United States. How will DLA Piper’s associates in low Earth orbit take the news? The cost of living on the Mars Opportunity rover isn’t going down.

Oh, I kid, DLA. Having global client services is actually a good thing. Congratulations. Associates in DLA Mariana Trench can afford to stop swimming to work and take mermen rickshaws instead.

# Biglaw Partner Suspended For Watching Porn At Work
## Each and every part of this story is disgusting.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 9, 2018 at 12:12 PMNovember 12, 2018 at 10:36 AM
10
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/biglaw-partner-suspended-for-watching-porn-at-work/&text=Biglaw%20Partner%20Suspended%20For%20Watching%20Porn%20At%20Work)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/biglaw-partner-suspended-for-watching-porn-at-work/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/biglaw-partner-suspended-for-watching-porn-at-work/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It’s not every day that a Biglaw partner gets suspended for watching porn in his office, but today is apparently that day.

It seems that Hogan Lovells has disciplined an unnamed partner in its London office after he was caught watching an adult video while he was on the clock — and it wasn’t the firm’s IT department that made the illicit discovery. According to [RollOnFriday](https://www.rollonfriday.com/news-content/exclusive-hogan-lovells-partner-suspended-after-rival-lawyer-films-him-watching-porn), an attorney at the law firm Irwin Mitchell, which is located directly across a narrow street from HoLove, looked out the window and witnessed the Biglaw partner misbehaving at his desk. The Irwin Mitchell lawyer then whipped out a cellphone, filmed the partner in question as he indulged in adult activities at his desk, and sent the video to the Hogan Lovells HR team. Sources at the firm told RollOnFriday that this was a case of “Hogan (Self) Lovells,” which makes the situation all the worse.

Hogan Lovells has launched an investigation into this partner’s predilection for pornography. “We were made aware of an individual in our office misusing their computer to watch adult material,” a Hogan Lovells spokesperson said in a statement given to [ALM International](https://www.law.com/2018/11/09/hogan-lovells-suspends-partner-for-watching-adult-video-at-work-396-9099/). “Such behavior is unacceptable and we have suspended them pending a full internal investigation.” Here are more details from the firm:

“We didn’t block access to websites unless they represented a cybersecurity risk (e.g. they have malware on them),” the spokesperson said. “The nature of our work for clients sometimes means we need to carry out investigations in areas which require us to have flexible access. We have reviewed and tightened this policy.”

We’re not sure what’s more disgusting, the fact that a Biglaw partner may have been masturbating at his desk while watching porn at work, or the fact that a voyeur lawyer from a firm across the street watched the act as it happened, decided to film it, and then distributed another form of porn to Hogan Lovells. As an FYI for all parties who were involved in this gross scenario, you’re supposed to be performing pro bono work in your spare time, not pro boner work. You’re all gross. We seriously hope this helps!

[EXCLUSIVE Hogan Lovells partner suspended after rival lawyer films him watching porn](https://www.rollonfriday.com/news-content/exclusive-hogan-lovells-partner-suspended-after-rival-lawyer-films-him-watching-porn) [RollOnFriday]
[Hogan Lovells Suspends London Partner for Watching Porn at Work](https://www.law.com/2018/11/09/hogan-lovells-suspends-partner-for-watching-adult-video-at-work-396-9099/) [ALM International]

# A&O Shearman Names Its First Global Leadership Team
## A&O Shearman's new leaders are excited to take the reins at what's poised to become the third-largest firm in the world.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 1, 2024 at 3:15 PMMarch 1, 2024 at 1:57 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/ao-shearman-names-its-first-global-leadership-team/&text=A&O%20Shearman%20Names%20Its%20First%20Global%20Leadership%20Team)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/ao-shearman-names-its-first-global-leadership-team/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/ao-shearman-names-its-first-global-leadership-team/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

I am honored that the partnership has put its trust in me to lead A&O Shearman as its first senior partner.

Working closely with Hervé [Ekué], Adam [Hakki], Doreen [Lilienfeld], and other senior leadership, as A&O Shearman we will take forward our combined expertise and deep legal knowledge to achieve unparalleled outcomes for our clients on their increasingly complex legal and commercial challenges, wherever they and we operate in the world.

— [Khalid Garousha](https://www.allenovery.com/en-gb/global/people/Khalid-Garousha), who was recently elected as senior partner of A&O Shearman, commenting on what he and his leadership team will be able to [accomplish for the newly merged firm](https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2024/03/01/2838905/0/en/A-O-Shearman-Announces-First-Senior-Leadership-Roles.html) in the future. Effective May 1, Garousha will be joined by [Hervé Ekué](https://www.allenovery.com/en-gb/global/people/Herv%C3%A9-Eku%C3%A9) as managing partner, [Adam Hakki](https://www.shearman.com/en/people/h/hakki-adam) as co-chair of the firm’s global board and executive committee (as well as chair of the firm’s U.S. business), and [Doreen Lilienfeld](https://www.shearman.com/en/people/l/lilienfeld-doreen) as co-managing partner of the firm’s U.S. business. [Wim Dejonghe](https://www.allenovery.com/en-gb/global/people/Wim-Dejonghe), Allen & Overy’s current senior partner, had this to say about the merged firm’s new senior leadership team: “A&O Shearman will bring together some of the greatest legal talent in the world while maintaining a focus on clients, our people and wider society. I’m delighted to pass the leadership baton to Khalid, Hervé, Adam, and Doreen on May 1, and I wish them all every success in their new roles at A&O Shearman.”

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) and [Threads](https://www.threads.net/@stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Quinn Emanuel Partner Warned By Federal Judge About Losing His Cool
## There's an awful lot of money on the line.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 6, 2022 at 3:28 PMDecember 6, 2022 at 2:48 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/quinn-emanuel-partner-warned-by-federal-judge-about-losing-his-cool/&text=Quinn%20Emanuel%20Partner%20Warned%20By%20Federal%20Judge%20About%20Losing%20His%20Cool)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/quinn-emanuel-partner-warned-by-federal-judge-about-losing-his-cool/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/quinn-emanuel-partner-warned-by-federal-judge-about-losing-his-cool/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


Quinn Emanuel represented a class of healthcare insurers in an Affordable Care Act case against the federal government, and secured a $3.7 billion settlement. For their efforts — and the risk associated with taking on the contingency case — the trial court awarded them $185 million in legal fees.

Partner Derek Shaffer had to appear before the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit to defend the large size of the award against the complaints of class objectors. And as [reported by Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/legal/litigation/us-appeals-court-questions-185-mln-award-law-firm-quinn-emanuel-2022-12-05/), it did not appear to go particularly well:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
During argument, the appeals court appeared concerned by what appeared to be the Federal Claims judge not performing a “lodestar cross-check,” which involves a review of hourly rates and the number of hours worked on a case. “You put the world on notice. There will be a lodestar cross-check. She didn’t do it,” Chief Judge Kimberly Moore told Shaffer.

The class objectors, represented at oral argument by Sheppard Mullin, suggested attorneys fees of $8.8 million. That must be one hell of a lodestar cross-check if the proper amount of fees is a mere 4.8 percent of the award! Biglaw elites may look down their noses at plaintiffs’ work — particularly of the contingency variety — but society needs these suits. As Judge Posner famously described “the realistic alternative to a class action is not 17 million individual suits, but zero individual suits.” Everyone waits to object after the case is all nice and settled, but as Shaffer indicated during argument, Quinn Emanuel took on a real risk of NEVER getting compensated, noting the government “is not a defendant who is likely to settle — this is not a defendant who fears being subjected” to a large penalty.

And having that much cash on the line apparently made Shaffer a little testy. And Judge Moore was quick to point it out:

“Counsel, I’m trying to … figure out to myself why you’re … pointing your finger at us and sort of yelling at the court,” Moore remarked. She added: “It’s your money. If I had $187 [sic] million on the line, I’d probably lose my cool a little bit, too — so go for it.”

# Morning Docket: 06.29.17
## * Phone sex operators are suing over labor law violations. Because, fittingly, you're not supposed to be able to f**k phone sex operators. [[Law.com](http://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2017/06/28/phone-sex-workers-sue-over-low-wages-long-hours/)] * The National Law Journal continues to milk its ability to count [because that's value add journalism!](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/06/the-500-largest-law-firms/) Today they count lawyers by city. [[National Law Journal](http://www.nationallawjournal.com/id=1202791850104)] * A list of high profile pro bono matters that Biglaw firms have taken on. Does your firm make the list? [[American Lawyer](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202791116930/17-Pro-Bono-Matters-That-Big-Law-Championed/)] * Newly revealed FIFA report finds "appearance of improprieties." Yes, awarding an athletic tournament to a country with 120 degree weather and a slave labor bid does appear improper. Glad we got to the bottom of that. [[Corporate Counsel](http://www.corpcounsel.com/id=1202791815063/Previously-Secret-FIFA-Report-Finds-Appearance-of-Improprieties/)] * Lawyers explain their travel hacks. [[ABA Journal](http://www.abajournal.com/magazine/article/attorney_business_travel_strategies/)] * Divorce lawyer is also a matador. This isn't some kind of metaphor -- he fights bulls. [[Chicago Tribune](http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/ct-dwyane-wade-attorney-bullfighter-0629-chicago-inc-20170628-story.html)] * Nikki Haley becomes the latest official to run into Hatch Act trouble. [[NPR](http://www.npr.org/2017/06/27/534605617/ethics-group-says-u-n-ambassador-nikki-haleys-retweet-violated-a-federal-law)] * Justice Breyer is the most talkative justice on the Supreme Court. I wonder who's the least talkative... [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/newyork/articles/938415/the-most-talkative-justice-of-the-high-court-term)]
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 29, 2017 at 8:17 AM

# $4 Billion In Gross Revenue Is A Crap Ton Of Revenue
## This Biglaw firm had a great 2019.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onApril 24, 2020 at 6:32 PMApril 24, 2020 at 3:38 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/4-billion-in-gross-revenue-is-a-crap-ton-of-revenue/&text=$4%20Billion%20In%20Gross%20Revenue%20Is%20A%20Crap%20Ton%20Of%20Revenue)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/4-billion-in-gross-revenue-is-a-crap-ton-of-revenue/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/4-billion-in-gross-revenue-is-a-crap-ton-of-revenue/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


Which Biglaw firm posted the most revenue in 2019, according to data collected by ALM?

Hint: The firm posted $4,154,600,000 in gross revenue last year, making it the only firm to cross the $4 billion threshold.

# Former Biglaw Chair Died By Suicide, Inquest Reveals
## He's remembered as an 'inspirational leader.'
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJune 11, 2020 at 12:43 PMJune 11, 2020 at 12:14 PM
36
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/former-biglaw-chair-died-by-suicide-inquest-reveals/&text=Former%20Biglaw%20Chair%20Died%20By%20Suicide,%20Inquest%20Reveals)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/former-biglaw-chair-died-by-suicide-inquest-reveals/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/former-biglaw-chair-died-by-suicide-inquest-reveals/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Paul Rawlinson

Back in 2018, Baker McKenzie then-Global Chair, Paul Rawlinson, took a [temporary leave](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/global-chair-of-biglaw-firm-taking-temporary-leave-due-to-exhaustion/?rf=1) from the firm due to “exhaustion.” The following year, [Rawlinson passed away](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/04/biglaw-chair-dies-after-taking-leave-for-exhaustion/), though not many details were known about his death at that time. Now we’ve learned that he died by suicide.

Law.com [is reporting](https://www.law.com/2020/06/10/former-baker-mckenzie-chief-paul-rawlinson-died-by-suicide-inquest-hears-405-62228/) that during a virtual inquest held yesterday by the Surrey Coroner’s Court in the U.K., it was revealed Rawlinson died by suicide. They also heard that Rawlinson was suffering an “acute depressive illness,” and was undergoing treatment at a Swiss rehabilitation center, Kusnacht Practice, at the time of his death.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)

If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
The firm made the following statement:

“Paul’s sudden death in April 2019 was a tragedy, most obviously for his family, but also for Baker McKenzie, where he had been a long serving partner and inspirational leader in various roles. He was a man of enormous charisma and energy,” Baker McKenzie said in a statement Wednesday. “The circumstances surrounding Paul’s death are a private matter for his family and we continue to request appropriate respect for that. As painful as events have been for his many friends and colleagues in the firm, our thoughts throughout have been with Paul’s wife and children, and will continue to be, as they move forward.”

These details of Rawlinson’s death provide a poignant reminder of the mental health issues that often run rampant in Biglaw. If you or someone you know is depressed and in need help, please call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline (1-800-273-8255) or a lawyer assistance program in your state.

# Biglaw Firm Offers Students Who Didn't Get Summer Associate Jobs The Chance To Work As 'Virtual' Summer Associates
## This is an awesome résumé line -- minus the Biglaw cash, of course.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMay 15, 2020 at 4:30 PMMay 15, 2020 at 3:11 PM
11
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/biglaw-firm-offers-students-who-didnt-get-summer-associate-jobs-the-chance-to-work-as-virtual-summer-associates/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Offers%20Students%20Who%20Didn’t%20Get%20Summer%20Associate%20Jobs%20The%20Chance%20To%20Work%20As%20‘Virtual’%20Summer%20Associates)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/biglaw-firm-offers-students-who-didnt-get-summer-associate-jobs-the-chance-to-work-as-virtual-summer-associates/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/biglaw-firm-offers-students-who-didnt-get-summer-associate-jobs-the-chance-to-work-as-virtual-summer-associates/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
We see this as an extremely valuable learning exercise for these students to well prepare them to finish out the second and or third year of law school and have on their resume a very valuable experience having worked through and lived through this simulated exercise over eight weeks.

[It will be] just like being a summer associate in a law firm.

— [Michael Volpe](https://www.venable.com/professionals/v/michael-j-volpe), co-chair of Venable’s labor and employment practice group, commenting on the firm’s [simulated summer associate experience at a “virtual” law firm](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/venable-new-york-law-school-offer-virtual-summer-firm-program). Venable has teamed up with New York Law School to create and put on this eight-week training program in record time. “I think people recognize what this summer means to a large group of law students who otherwise will lose their summer and will lose out on tremendous opportunities,” said [Anthony Crowell](https://www.nyls.edu/faculty/faculty-profiles/faculty_profiles/anthony_w_crowell/), dean of NYLS.

# Attention Associates: Tell Us About Your Health Plan
## Is your firm screwing you on health care?
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onNovember 29, 2017 at 10:58 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/attention-associates-tell-us-about-your-health-plan/&text=Attention%20Associates:%20Tell%20Us%20About%20Your%20Health%20Plan)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/attention-associates-tell-us-about-your-health-plan/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/attention-associates-tell-us-about-your-health-plan/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
When we reported on [Simpson Thacher’s bonus announcement](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/biglaw-firm-matches-cravath-but-are-they-cutting-associate-compensation-while-no-ones-looking/), our tipsters pointed out that changes to the firm’s health plan would result in associates paying more for less coverage over the coming year. Happy Holidays!

That inspired more than a few tipsters to point out that Simpson’s new plan — while increasing the burden on employees next year — may not even be the stingiest health plan out there. One tipster claimed that one elite New York firm’s employee contribution is $60 more per pay period than Simpson’s and another top-of-the-heap firm plan is charging 60 percent on top of what Simpson is.

We’ve not gotten secondary confirmation on either of these tips, but if firms — big firms, small firms, or boutiques — are routinely bleeding associates on their health care, that’s something we want to know. Frankly, we don’t want only bad news, either! If a firm is going above and beyond to provide stellar care for cheap, we want to know that too.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
So we’re asking our tipsters — one and all — to tell us what their firms are charging for health care. Attorneys have overlooked the details of their health plans for too long — it’s not only literally a life-and-death issue, but it can really eat into your salary too. Let us know [by email](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Health), by text message (646-820-8477), or by tweet ([@ATLblog](https://twitter.com/atlblog)). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

Obviously these are all very much “first world problems.” Attorneys aren’t roaming the streets uncovered and the contributions they make to health care aren’t really breaking their bank accounts in the grand scheme of things. But that’s no reason to be complacent. Your bosses are putting more in their pockets and hoping you feel too ashamed to complain. Don’t fall for it.

[Joe Patrice](http://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/) is an editor at Above the Law and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](http://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). Feel free to [email](mailto:joe@abovethelaw.com) any tips, questions, or comments. Follow him on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/josephpatrice) if you’re interested in law, politics, and a healthy dose of college sports news.

# Morning Docket: 08.03.16
## * Singer Kesha has dropped her lawsuit in California against producer Dr. Luke, but will continue her appeal in New York. She says she dropped the suit because she's "focused on getting back to work," but Dr. Luke's lawyer says it's because she has "no chance of winning." Ouch, that's got to sting. [[People](http://www.people.com/article/kesha-dismisses-california-lawsuit-agaisnt-dr-luke-28-new-songs)] * Get off my lawn, you damn kids! A New Jersey personal injury attorney has filed a class-action lawsuit against Niantic, the company behind Pokemon Go, for the "unlawful and wrongful" invasion of his property. It seems that in the rush to catch 'em all, people have been gathering outside of his home, knocking on his door, and asking to enter his backyard. [[WSJ Law Blog](http://blogs.wsj.com/law/2016/08/02/not-in-my-backyard-new-jersey-attorney-sues-over-pokemon-invasion/?ref=/blogs/law)] * Following up on his tentative oral ruling, Juge Gonzalo P. Curiel has ruled that a Trump University fraud case filed against Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump may proceed to trial, but he refused to release Trump's videotaped deposition. We suppose that the transcript will have to be good enough. [[New York Times](http://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/03/us/politics/trump-university-case.html)] * "These are things that don't just affect one job; it keeps women's wages down over their entire lifetime." Thanks to a new law geared toward closing the gender wage gap, in Massachusetts, it is now illegal for employers to ask about applicants' salary history before offering them jobs. This goes into effect in 2018. [[DealBook / New York Times](http://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/03/business/dealbook/wage-gap-massachusetts-law-salary-history.html)] * "We are confidently looking to the future." Following a series of "regrettable departures" and a capital call that successfully raised about $18.4 million from the firm's existing partners, it looks like the "modernization" and restructuring of the King & Wood Mallesons partnership is finally going to be drawing to a close. [[Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/end-in-sight-for-king-wood-mallesons-restructuring/)] * Jenner & Block has teamed up with the University of Chicago Law School to create a Supreme Court and Appellate Clinic, with the goal of "educat[ing] and train[ing] the next generation of extraordinary appellate advocates and continu[ing] the tradition of helping clients hanks their most important litigation problems." Congratulations! [[ABA Journal](http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/jenner_and_university_of_chicago_law_school_open_scotus_clinic)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onAugust 3, 2016 at 8:58 AMAugust 2, 2016 at 11:32 PM

# Big Raises Ahead For This Biglaw Firm
## Of course the firm is stepping up with raises.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onFebruary 28, 2022 at 12:02 PMFebruary 28, 2022 at 11:50 AM
10
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/paul-hastings-raises/&text=Big%20Raises%20Ahead%20For%20This%20Biglaw%20Firm)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/paul-hastings-raises/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/paul-hastings-raises/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Want a great way to warm up a cold February day in Biglaw? Well, raises are a sure fire way to warm the cockles of associate hearts.

Paul Hastings, a firm with over a billion dollars in revenue, making it #27 on the Am Law 100, has announced their own raises. And, you guessed it, the elite firm will be matching the prevailing market rate set by Milbank and Davis Polk.

The new associate compensation grid at the firm is as follows:

Associate Salary Scale

Class Year	Salary
2014+	$396,500
2015	$381,000
2016	$360,500
2017	$335,000
2018	$293,500
2019	$250,000
2020	$225,000
2021	$215,000
The increases are retroactive to January 31 and applies to the U.S. and São Paulo offices.

You can read the [full memo on the next page.](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/paul-hastings-raises/2/)

[*** Wondering if the grass is greener on the in-house side? Click here for a look inside the black box of corporate counsel pay in our 2021 In-House Compensation Report. ***](https://info.abovethelaw.com/2021-in-house-compensation-survey-report)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for all of your help!

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22)).

# Top 50 Biglaw Firm Rolls Out Generous Bonuses, And Eligibility Includes Time Billed For 'Unplugging'
## More firms should have programs like this!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onDecember 14, 2021 at 6:02 PMDecember 14, 2021 at 5:55 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/orrick-bonus-2021/&text=Top%2050%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Rolls%20Out%20Generous%20Bonuses,%20And%20Eligibility%20Includes%20Time%20Billed%20For%20‘Unplugging’)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/orrick-bonus-2021/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/orrick-bonus-2021/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It’s officially bonus o’clock at yet another Biglaw firm. One by one, members of the Am Law 100 have made their own bonus announcements, matching the prevailing market bonus scale (and sometimes beating it for associates whose performance in 2021 was extraordinary in terms of billable hours and/or client service).

The latest firm to share the wealth with associates and counsel through its year-end bonus program is Orrick Herrington & Sutcliffe. The firm brought in $1,152,850,000 gross revenue in 2020, putting it in 35th place in the most recent Am Law 100 ranking. Orrick’s bonus schedule should look quite familiar if you’ve been following Above the Law this bonus season.



[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
That’s a Cravath/Davis Polk match, and according to Orrick’s memo, its hardest working associates and counsel will be eligible for additional bonus amounts. The firm has also committed to pay special bonuses to its career associates and analytics project attorneys.

The firm’s 1950 hours baseline for bonus eligibility includes up to 100 hours of a combination of training, DEI, business development, innovation, and other forms of firm and self-investment; pro bono hours; as well as up to 40 hours of time devoted to unplugging (i.e., time for attorneys to take care of themselves and their families and to invest in their own mental health and wellness). As noted in the firm’s memo, Orrick calls its [“Unplug on Us” program](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/top-50-biglaw-firm-rolls-out-incredible-bonus-eligible-time-off-policy/) “an important reflection of what we collectively value.”

Congratulations to everyone at Orrick on their year-end and special bonuses!

(Flip to the next page to read the full memo from Orrick.)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for all of your help!

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

[  ](/)	[Home](/) | [Archive](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/archive/) | [RSS](/feed/) | [Twitter](https://www.twitter.com/howappealing) | [Contact](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)

	

Friday, December 23, 2022
“A Federal Court Just Took Judicial Obstruction of Biden’s Presidency to a New Level; The 5th Circuit’s latest salvo is even more dangerous than it seems”: Online at Slate, law professor [Jody Madeira](https://law.indiana.edu/about/people/details/madeira-jody-l.html) has [this jurisprudence essay](https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2022/12/biden-vaccine-mandate-federal-contractors-fifth-circuit.html) about [a ruling](https://www.ca5.uscourts.gov/opinions/pub/22/22-30019-CV0.pdf) that a divided three-judge panel of the [U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit](http://www.ca5.uscourts.gov) issued Monday.

Posted at [9:18 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2022/12/23/#196306) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Hamilton County Prosecutor Appointed as Supreme Court Justice”: Court News Ohio has [a report](https://www.courtnewsohio.gov/bench/2022/DetersJustice_122322.asp) that begins, “Joseph T. Deters, the longest-serving prosecutor in Hamilton County history, is appointed to serve as the 163rd justice of the Supreme Court of Ohio.”

Posted at [9:01 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2022/12/23/#196300) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“The problem is too many Americans no longer trust the Supreme Court. The solution is clear.” Law professor [Erwin Chemerinsky](https://www.law.berkeley.edu/our-faculty/faculty-profiles/erwin-chemerinsky/#tab_profile) has [this essay](https://www.sacbee.com/opinion/op-ed/article267179101.html) online at The Sacramento Bee.

Posted at [8:56 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2022/12/23/#196294) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Why the Jan. 6 Committee Let Ginni and Clarence Thomas Off the Hook: When you’re a justice, they let you do it.” Dahlia Lithwick has [this jurisprudence essay](https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2022/12/january-6-report-summary-clarence-thomas-ginni-ethics.html) online at Slate.

Posted at [8:52 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2022/12/23/#196288) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Hochul Taps First Latino Judge to Head New York’s Top Court; The nomination of Hector D. LaSalle, a moderate who leads a state court division, could anger Democratic lawmakers who wanted the governor to name a progressive”: Rebecca Davis O’Brien has [this article](https://www.nytimes.com/2022/12/22/nyregion/new-york-appeals-court-nomination-hochul.html) in today’s edition of The New York Times.

Denis Slattery of The New York Daily News reports that “[Opposition mounts against Hochul’s chief judge pick as unions, Dems and advocates disapprove](https://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/new-york-elections-government/ny-hector-lasalle-chief-judge-nomination-20221223-sqad5ls2hjeq7noww6q6m4zkha-story.html).”

Keshia Clukey and Fawn Johnson of Bloomberg Law report that “[Hochul Angers Unions, Progressives With Top NY Judge Pick](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/us-law-week/hochul-angers-unions-progressives-with-top-ny-judge-nomination).”

At his “New York Appeals” blog, Rob Rosborough has a post titled “[Governor Hochul Nominates Presiding Justice Hector LaSalle to be New York’s First Latino Chief Judge!](https://nysappeals.com/2022/12/22/governor-hochul-nominates-presiding-justice-hector-lasalle-to-be-new-yorks-first-latino-chief-judge/)”

In commentary, online at Slate, Alexander Sammon and Mark Joseph Stern have a jurisprudence essay titled “[Kathy Hochul’s Nominee for New York’s Top Judge Is an Absolute Disaster for Democrats; The governor had a chance to reshape the state’s highest court; She blew it](https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2022/12/kathy-hochul-hector-lasalle-new-york-judicial-nomination.html).”

And at his “Law Dork” Substack site, Chris Geidner has a post titled “[New York’s Hochul, Ohio’s DeWine both pick conservative prosecutors for state high court openings](https://www.lawdork.com/p/new-yorks-hochul-ohios-dewine-both).”

Posted at [8:46 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2022/12/23/#196282) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Florida Supreme Court approves DeSantis call for coronavirus vaccine grand jury”: John Kennedy of The Tallahassee Democrat has [this report](https://www.tallahassee.com/story/news/politics/2022/12/22/florida-supreme-court-gives-ok-to-desantis-covid-vaccine-grandy-jury/69752353007/).

Posted at [8:25 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2022/12/23/#196276) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“For John Eastman and Clarence Thomas, an intellectual kinship stretching back decades; The Supreme Court justice and the lawyer referred by the House Jan. 6 panel for criminal investigation became acquainted years before Eastman served as Thomas’s clerk”: Emma Brown and Rosalind S. Helderman of The Washington Post have [this report](https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/2022/12/23/john-eastman-clarence-thomas-clerk/).

Posted at [12:34 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2022/12/23/#196270) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)

# Partners Should More Often Admit To Associates When They Are Wrong
## No one likes to admit that they are wrong, but sometimes it's necessary.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onJuly 7, 2021 at 5:17 PMJuly 7, 2021 at 2:54 PM
32
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/partners-should-more-often-admit-to-associates-when-they-are-wrong/&text=Partners%20Should%20More%20Often%20Admit%20To%20Associates%20When%20They%20Are%20Wrong)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/partners-should-more-often-admit-to-associates-when-they-are-wrong/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/partners-should-more-often-admit-to-associates-when-they-are-wrong/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Being a law firm partner is a pretty big deal in the legal industry. Depending on the firm, only a select few attorneys are elevated to partnership, and this usually means that an attorney has the skill and experience needed to be a firm leader. However, partners of course do not know everything nor are they infallible. In my experience, partners may have a difficult time admitting they are wrong even when pressed with persuasive information by associates, and this can lead to a number of negative consequences.

One of the biggest reasons why partners do not like admitting when they are wrong to associates is because it may impact their pride. Partners often have much more experience than associates, and they accordingly should know more about the law and strategies that can be deployed in a case. However, this does not mean that a partner’s understanding is never wrong, especially since the law is constantly changing, and partners cannot be expected to know everything about everything. Moreover, associates who recently attended law school may have a fresher understanding of the law and legal research techniques that can be used to arrive at the correct answer.

One time earlier in my career, a partner tasked me with researching how our firm could stay a decision pending an appeal. The ordinary situation, as this partner described it, was to post an undertaking in the amount of the judgment so that the party that won the judgment would not be prejudiced while the appeals process occurred. However, I found in my research that when an insured was covered by a policy of insurance, we may not need to post an undertaking, and we may be able to merely provide some paperwork by the insurance company saying that the carrier would pay the amount of the judgment if there was an adverse decision on appeal. This was a much more favorable situation to us since insurance was involved in our case, and this could eliminate the need to post a substantial sum of money.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
I brought this research to the partner working on the file, and he would not believe that we could simply file some paperwork from the insurance company to stay the appeal. He read the provision on point that explicitly permitted this to occur from his own desk reference book, and he still would not believe that this could occur. At one point he even asked another lawyer to come into his office and asked this lawyer to read the particular provision at issue and side with him, but of course the language was in black and white that such a process was available. The partner let his pride get in the way of apprehending a procedure of which he was not familiar, and he had an extremely difficult time admitting that he was wrong.

Another common situation in which partners have a difficult time admitting they are wrong is when it comes to research projects. At bigger firms, partners may task associates with researching small snippets of a brief or finding case law which supports a proposition that a partner wishes to include in a brief. However, sometimes the proposition that the partner wants authority on is wrong, and case law does not exist to support the point. Partners may not accept that their arguments cannot be supported and force associates to keep looking for authority that does not exist, which can waste resources. Partners should accept that associates conducting the research itself are more likely to know what can and cannot be supported by the law and not be upset if expectation are not satisfied after research is complete.

Another time when partners should more often admit that they are wrong to associates is if associates think of better ways to make arguments. Unfortunately, partners are often too willing to think that their experience and age makes them better tacticians than associates who may be closer to the research of a matter.

One time, I was tasked with filing a motion to compel a party to provide materials for our expert to inspect. The party argued that they needed to keep the materials pursuant to state law, and as such, they could not be compelled to turn it over. The partner wanted to argue that there was a very low chance that the party would be caught not possessing the required materials by authorities so the court should compel their production to us.

I have no idea why the partner thought a court would countenance skirting the law, but I had a better idea. After reviewing the applicable authorities, I suggested arguing that the party was merely loaning us the materials, and since the materials would be returned, and since the party maintained a possessory interest in the materials, the law would be satisfied. The partner had a hard time buying my argument even though I was closer to the research and knew what points we could make to persuade a court to compel production.

All told, no one likes to admit that they are wrong, and partners may think that their experience and age makes them more qualified to render legal opinions. However, associates are often closer to the research, and partners should more often admit they are wrong to avoid inefficiencies and best serve clients.

Jordan Rothman is a partner of [The Rothman Law Firm](http://www.rothmanlawyer.com/), a full-service New York and New Jersey law firm. He is also the founder of [Student Debt Diaries](https://studentdebtdiaries.com/), a website discussing how he paid off his student loans. # Nationwide Layoff Watch: Banished Beyond The Gates
## The cuts, which hit multiple departments and offices, are just the latest manifestation of upheaval at the firm.
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onFebruary 9, 2017 at 2:31 PMFebruary 15, 2017 at 11:01 AM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/nationwide-layoff-watch-banished-beyond-the-gates/&text=Nationwide%20Layoff%20Watch:%20Banished%20Beyond%20The%20Gates)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/nationwide-layoff-watch-banished-beyond-the-gates/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/nationwide-layoff-watch-banished-beyond-the-gates/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Lawyers at [K&L Gates](https://abovethelaw.com/law-firms/kl-gates/) have to worry about dragging the firm [into political controversy](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/biglaw-managing-partner-to-entire-firm-stfu-on-scotus/). Support staff at K&L Gates have a much bigger concern: job security.

Last week, according to several of our sources at the firm, “scores” of support staff were laid off at K&L Gates (the exact number is unknown). The laid-off employees included employees who had been with K&L Gates (or its legacy firms) for several decades, as well as new employees who had been at the firm just a short time (and who presumably left other good jobs to join KLG).

In terms of departments, the affected employees included nearly the entire IT training team, the entire Q/A team, Tier 2 Support, and at least one Project Manager. In terms of offices, they included Seattle, Chicago, Dallas, Melbourne, and possibly others. The affected employees did not include any upper-level management, “compounding the problem of an already too top-heavy org structure,” as one tipster told us.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Severance was provided in the amount of two weeks per year, plus benefits until the end of February and one month of career placement services (although the group providing placement services is so busy that it’s difficult to speak with anyone). This is just the latest manifestation of upheaval in the ranks of staff at K&L Gates, which last month witnessed the unexplained departure of the firm’s Chief Information Officer (CIO).

“They do not understand the importance of the positions they eliminated,” one affected individual told us. “Clients will suffer with no support to the users.”

We presented the foregoing information to the firm, which issued this response, through a spokesperson:

K&L Gates takes pride in providing professional growth opportunities for employees at all levels. The firm works to assure the right employees are performing the right jobs in order to maximize client service and efficiency. As is the case with any global professional services organization, we periodically review our staffing needs and make adjustments for the good of the firm and its clients.

From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Fair enough. In these efficiency-focused times for law firms, cuts are sometimes necessary. But that economic reality doesn’t make things any easier for the K&L Gates employees who just lost their jobs.

Do you have any additional details on what’s going on at K&L Gates? [Please drop us a line](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=NRF%20Layoffs%20/%20Office%20Closure). We wish all those who may be affected at the firm the best of luck while they seek new job opportunities in the legal industry and beyond.

If your firm or organization is reducing the ranks of its lawyers or staff, whether through open layoffs, stealth layoffs, or voluntary buyouts, please don’t hesitate to let us know. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Layoffs) or text us (646-820-8477). Thank you for your help in keeping law firms honest.

UPDATE (5:45 p.m.): We don’t know how many staffers were affected, but we are probably talking about dozens on a firm-wide basis, given what this source had to say:

The K&L Gates layoffs hit Pittsburgh staff particularly hard. They aren’t finished. Tough to get official counts, but close to 30 staff. Secretaries and paralegals that I know got 12 weeks of severance.

At this point, no lawyers known to be involved in cuts. They need to cut underperforming associates/income-level partners and particularly focus on the gluttony of unnecessary managers.

From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
UPDATE (2/10/2017, 10:05 a.m.): A different tipster offers this defense of the firm:

To its credit, K&L Gates used to be very humane about firing both staff and lawyers. While Latham Lathamed, KLG just kept people on while they were still slow. One associate in the 2011 class literally didn’t bill one hour for the first five months she was there (I understand she wrote a great treatise chapter). Unfortunately, it got really bloated, which is part of the reason why partners weren’t getting top dollar compared to peer firms. Recognizing the existential threat of partner departures, they’re making hard choices they should have made a long time ago. They had way too many staffers. Probably twice as many as they needed in some offices.

If this source is right, then it was only a matter of time before such a reckoning took place.

UPDATE (2/15/2017, 11:05 a.m.): Please see [this update](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/nationwide-layoff-watch-150-to-200-jobs-is-a-lot-of-jobs/) for additional information. Specifically:

1. The cuts affected an estimated 150 to 200 staffers.

2. Whether the cuts included upper-level management depends on how broadly you define “upper-level”; directors in admin, HR, and marketing departments were affected.

3. Severance arrangements varied from employee to employee.

# Law Firm Merger Trend Continues In 2020
## More law firm merger madness.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJanuary 6, 2020 at 5:15 PMJanuary 6, 2020 at 4:25 PM
20
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/01/law-firm-merger-trend-continues-in-2020/&text=Law%20Firm%20Merger%20Trend%20Continues%20In%202020)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/01/law-firm-merger-trend-continues-in-2020/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/01/law-firm-merger-trend-continues-in-2020/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It’s still early in 2020, so you may still be feeling the whole “new year, new me” vibe. And that’s cool, I’m still feeling the resolutions myself. But when it comes to the law firm merger landscape, 2020 is shaping up to look a lot like 2019. We saw a lot of law firm mergers last year, and now, not even a full week since the calendar flipped over there are two more mergers to talk about.

The first is the combination of Cincinnati-based Taft Stettinius & Hollister merging with Minneapolis-based Briggs & Morgan. The new entity, known simply as Taft, has 600+ lawyers and 12 offices. The combined revenue of the new firm will likely place them in the Am Law 100.

As [reported by](https://www.law.com/2020/01/03/taft-lathrop-gpm-officially-tie-the-knot-kicking-off-2020-law-firm-mergers/) Law.com, the powers in charge of the merger say there’s been a smooth transition:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
“There were no hiccups or problems we didn’t anticipate,” said Steven Ryan, the partner in charge of Taft’s Minneapolis office. Taft managing partner Robert Hicks expressed similar sentiments, saying while there was some “scrambling” at one point, “it couldn’t have gone any better.”

The second merger of 2020 sees the marriage of Kansas City, Missouri-based Lathrop Gage and Minneapolis-based Gray Plant Mooty, now known as Lathrop GPM. They newly expanded firm has ~400 lawyers across 14 offices. Lathrop GPM managing partner Cameron Garrison had good things to say about the change:

“As you can image, a combination of this size takes a lot of heavy lifting, and attorneys and staff throughout the organization have done a phenomenal job implementing the combination in a short amount of time,” Garrison said.

And don’t expect the merger madness to slow down any time soon.

### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Apart from Taft and Lathrop GPM, 10 more law firm mergers are scheduled to close in the first quarter of 2020, according to consultancy Fairfax Associates. This includes Dentons’ [combinations](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2019/10/07/dentons-combines-with-two-us-firms-in-one-go-launching-new-american-strategy-405-45784/) with Indianapolis-based Bingham Greenebaum Doll and Pittsburgh-based Cohen & Grigsby, as a part of Dentons’ “Golden Spike” strategy to ostensibly create the first national law firm in the U.S.

A Dentons spokeswoman said they “continue to anticipate launching sometime in January,” but wouldn’t give a specific date.

Plus, on February 1st, we expect to see the merger of two Biglaw firms Faegre Baker Daniels and Drinker Biddle & Reath. The new firm, Faegre Drinker Biddle & Reath, is expected to take its place in the top Am Law 50 with 1,300+ lawyers and 22 offices.

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, and host of [The Jabot podcast.](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA) AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter (@Kathryn1).

# As The World Churns
## Screw 'thoughts and prayers.' Screw 'there are no words.'
By [Jill Switzer](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jillswitzer/)  
onMay 26, 2022 at 4:46 PMMay 26, 2022 at 3:14 PM
12
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/as-the-world-churns/&text=As%20The%20World%20Churns)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/as-the-world-churns/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/as-the-world-churns/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
There seems to be a never-ending amount of callousness mixed with stupidity mixed with cognitive dissonance mixed with outright violence and horror these days.

The London office of Biglaw firm White & Case allegedly fired a partner who was suffering from mental health issues due to the loss of his wife to cancer. Disputing the fired partner’s claim and saying that the partner was terminated for “poor performance,” the catchall of all catchalls, the firm noted that “[sadness and grief](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/biglaw-firm-defends-firing-of-widower-noting-sadness-and-grief-are-not-disabilities/)” are not sufficiently disabling under British law.

Maybe that argument has to do with the whole British concepts of “stiff upper lip” and “carry on,” but how unfeeling can one be to not sympathize, empathize, whatever words you choose, with the death of a loved one? (I will talk about Uvalde later.)  And with more than 1 million COVID-related deaths in this country, how could anyone not have been touched personally by grief and sadness, a sense of a loss that is indeed forever? Amazingly heartless? Stupid? Res ipsa loquitur.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Bravo to Mark Herrmann, who reiterates what should be [a main tenet of law](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/the-perils-of-thinking-that-its-all-a-game/) practice, in that you don’t reach for the moon in litigation if your client is only entitled to a piece of green cheese. Whoever thinks that litigation, trying a case, is just a game is stupid. Even if freedoms and lives are not at stake as they are in criminal cases, civil cases of whatever nature are equally important to the parties involved, and to treat them without the requisite degree of seriousness is not only stupid, but malpractice. That’s why explaining to clients the value (or no value) of a case is essential. The failure to do that is also stupid and malpractice. Our job is to tell clients the good, the bad, and the ugly about their cases. They should not be seen just as ticking billable hours (whether a person or an entity) but with real-life problems that need to be resolved as best as possible, without bankrupting them. Isn’t solving problems, be they micro or macro, why we do what we do?

“Chutzpah” is one of my favorite words. Substitute “gall” or “nerve” for it, and you get the idea. So how about this for nerve, gall or chutzpah? One of the defendants awaiting trial arising out of the January 6, 2021, “house party” wanted to go on a trip outside the U.S. to celebrate that he was a winner in a sales contest at his company. (Full disclosure: I have been to several of those, courtesy of my ex-husband, many years ago, and it is a week or so of good times. However, he was not awaiting trial on any offense, except for his long-held grudge against the Dodgers moving from Brooklyn to LA.) So, it’s a [great bench slap](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/benchslap-judge-dropkicks-capitol-riot-defendants-request-for-luxury-mexican-vacation/) when a court tells a defendant how it really feels about the defendant’s untimely request to travel to Cabo. [    ](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/benchslap-judge-dropkicks-capitol-riot-defendants-request-for-luxury-mexican-vacation/)

And here in the Central District of California, Federal District Judge Otis Wright has [washed his hands](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/federal-judge-up-and-quits-case-after-getting-annoyed-with-attorney/) of a criminal trial he was presiding over. It was, in a sense, an “off with their heads,” or more particularly the public defender who was doing what lawyers are supposed to do, provide a vigorous defense, and make a record for any appeal. If only we lawyers could get rid of clients in the same way.

How about having [Elon Musk for a client](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/elon-musk-takes-time-out-from-failing-to-buy-twitter-to-fail-to-build-his-own-law-firm/)? I don’t know what your reaction may be, but mine is simple: pass. Talk about having an issue or two — or 20 — with client control. Do you think there is enough money in the world to be part of a law firm that he will hire, fire, direct, and control? And more than one general counsel at Tesla [has taken a hike](https://www.cnbc.com/2019/12/12/tesla-loses-its-third-general-counsel-in-the-last-year.html) from Tesla in the past few years. Calling all superheroes and others who don’t care about their reputations and who are willing to put themselves in harm’s way. A situation of cognitive dissonance?

### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
It will be easier to practice once the LSATs go the way of VCRs. (Remember those? Remember dial telephones?) The ABA may well drop all law school testing requirements. Say what? Yup, that bastion of tradition may well toss the LSAT. Some law schools have already [substituted the GRE](https://www.bestcolleges.com/news/2022/05/11/aba-lsat-law-school-admissions/) for admission purposes.

The cottage industry of LSAT prep will probably fall by the wayside. There are a number of things to complain about the test, not the least of which is the cost of prep, done often more than once, to present an aspiring lawyer in the most alluring light for law school admissions deans. As a result, good, even great, potential candidates for law school can’t jump the first barrier, which is the LSAT prep costs. And an LSAT prep can cost thousands in addition to the usual and customary fees for taking the LSAT itself. For many peeps, standardized tests have been dreadful ways to determine success in the first year of law school. It’s not predicative of any lawyering ability except the ability to do well on a standardized test. Law school admissions officers may now think about candidates more holistically, instead of an LSAT score and a GPA that might only reflect “easy A’s.”

So, when do the horrors end? Now [19 children and two adults are dead](https://www.cnn.com/videos/us/2022/05/24/chris-murphy-texas-elementary-school-shooting-vpx.cnn) in Uvalde, Texas. Screw “thoughts and prayers.” Screw “There are no words.” Remember Buffalo? Remember Orange County? And those two are just in the past week and a half. There are plenty of words, but too many people don’t want to say them. We lawyers earn our keep with words. We need to speak up and speak out.

Jill Switzer has been an active member of the State Bar of California for over 40 years. She remembers practicing law in a kinder, gentler time. She’s had a diverse legal career, including stints as a deputy district attorney, a solo practice, and several senior in-house gigs. She now mediates full-time, which gives her the opportunity to see dinosaurs, millennials, and those in-between interact — it’s not always civil. You can reach her by email at [oldladylawyer@gmail.com](mailto:oldladylawyer@gmail.com?subject=Your%20ATL%20column).

# When People Start Writing About You Destroying Your Firm, Things Aren't Going Well
## The New York Law Journal asks if Marc Kasowitz is hurting his firm. That's never a good sign.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 14, 2017 at 12:29 PMJune 14, 2017 at 1:16 PM
18
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/06/when-people-start-writing-about-you-destroying-your-firm-things-arent-going-well/&text=When%20People%20Start%20Writing%20About%20You%20Destroying%20Your%20Firm,%20Things%20Aren’t%20Going%20Well)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/06/when-people-start-writing-about-you-destroying-your-firm-things-arent-going-well/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/06/when-people-start-writing-about-you-destroying-your-firm-things-arent-going-well/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Marc Kasowitz (screenshot via YouTube)

The headline in the New York Law Journal is an ominous, but ultimately benign, “[Trump Case Leaves Marc Kasowitz’s Law Firm at a Crossroads.](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202789694971/Could-Marc-Kasowitz-Save-the-President-and-Lose-His-Law-Firm)” The URL, however, reveals that at some point in the life of the story it was titled “Could Marc Kasowitz Save the President and Lose His Law Firm?”

That’s… more ominous.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
And the fact that this sentiment made the leap from “what we’re all thinking” to the relatively staid pages of the New York Law Journal should worry anyone associated with the Kasowitz firm. On the bright side, there are enough unfilled ambassadorships right now for the rest of the firm to [follow David Friedman’s lead](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/03/kasowitz-benson-loses-name-partner-lots-of-money/).

There’s a reason firms are [falling all over themselves](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/05/no-one-wants-these-jobs/) to avoid working for Donald Trump. A notoriously meddlesome client with a well-documented history of stiffing his vendors would be reason enough to [steer clear](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/06/the-biglaw-firms-that-said-no-to-trump/) before adding that he’s the [least popular person in the country](http://time.com/4816799/donald-trump-disapproval-ratings-poll/). No one wants the attention that comes with carrying water for this administration. When Marc Kasowitz took on this job, none were happier than Jones Day, who thrilled at the opportunity to slink out of that ignominious limelight.

But Kasowitz’s firm — already down almost 100 attorneys and facing an over 7 percent revenue hit — faces unique risks that his high-profile turn only exacerbates. As the New York Law Journal puts it:

Few firms in the Am Law 200 have first-generation partners still running their firms. “Transitioning from a first-generation partnership to second generation is probably the hardest thing any firm does,” said legal management consultant Peter Zeughauser, speaking generally on succession planning. “And only a small number of firms make it when they have a single dominant partner.”

As managing partner of a large firm, Kasowitz, 64, stands out for his close involvement in his firm’s operations, including many of its most high-profile cases. He’s not just a rainmaker who steps back after cases are brought in, said one attorney keenly familiar with the firm.
“He’s going to be involved in anything important,” the attorney said. “Even though it’s a partnership, it’s his firm and he’s the leader.”

“How long can this firm last beyond Marc? … Most people feel it would break apart,” the lawyer said.

From Pilot and Above The Law  
And this doesn’t deal with the compounding embarrassments heaped on the firm from its… shall we say [“lackluster” drafting skills](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/06/marc-kasowitz-takes-break-from-partying-at-trump-hotel-to-talk-to-the-press/), questionable grasp of [ethical obligations to the unrepresented](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/06/is-marc-kasowitz-drunk-on-his-own-power/), and reports that Kasowitz is going around implying that there’s [fire underneath Trump’s smoke](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/06/kasowitz-supposedly-taking-credit-for-firing-preet-bharara/).

Thankfully for Marc Kasowitz, he’s got decades of results and existing client relationships that’ll keep business coming through the door despite these missteps. But new clients might get skittish when they start evaluating their options. Putting aside clients, why would any attorney want future potential employers scanning their résumé and wondering how they spell “Predisent”? Recruiting the next generation is a big part of midwifing a firm from its founders to the new guard, and this isn’t doing that process any favors. The reputational damage may be surmountable, but it is palpable.

Only time will tell where Kasowitz Benson goes from here. But it’s worth keeping an eye on the lateral market. The firm has already lost several key partners over the last year. It might just lose several more.

# Understanding The SEC’s Newly Proposed Climate Disclosure Requirements
## It’s crucial for today’s corporations and their lawyers to understand their obligations in relation to climate change, and how these latest proposed requirements might make those obligations more complex.
By STEPHANIE WILKINS  
onApril 29, 2022 at 2:14 PMApril 29, 2022 at 12:32 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/understanding-the-secs-newly-proposed-climate-disclosure-requirements/&text=Understanding%20The%20SEC’s%20Newly%20Proposed%20Climate%20Disclosure%20Requirements)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/understanding-the-secs-newly-proposed-climate-disclosure-requirements/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/understanding-the-secs-newly-proposed-climate-disclosure-requirements/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
In a much-anticipated move last month, the SEC proposed adding sweeping new climate change disclosure and reporting requirements to a number of regulations and SEC forms. Among the required new disclosures are information about company climate change policies, Greenhouse Gas Protocol Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions, and attestation requirements for accelerated and large accelerated filers. 

Companies should begin planning now for more extensive and complex disclosure requirements likely to be enacted from this proposal. To help you understand the proposed disclosure requirements and how to plan for them, PLI is offering a one-hour program, [Climate Disclosures – A Deep Dive Into the SEC’s Proposed New Governance, Strategy and Risk Disclosures](https://www.pli.edu/programs/climate-disclosures---a-deep-dive-into-the-secs-proposed-new-governance-strategy-and-risk-disclosures?t=live&tCode=CNS2_ATL01&utm_source=ATL01&utm_medium=DISPLAY&utm_campaign=CNS2).

In this session, an expert panel will address a number of key issues, including:

- The rationale for the SEC’s proposed changes 
- The foundations for the proposed rules in the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures framework
- Governance-related disclosures relating to Board of Directors’ oversight, disclosure of directors’ expertise considerations, Board considerations for risk evaluation, targets, and goals, and management’s role and process disclosures
- Strategy, business model, and outlook disclosures relating to potential business and financial impacts of climate-related risks, physical risks, transition risks, short-, medium-, and long-term time horizons, and internal carbon prices
- Risk management disclosures, including disclosure of processes for identifying, assessing, and managing climate-related risks
- Targets and goals disclosures
- Phase-in requirements 
- Recommended action steps 
You can register for the upcoming session [here](https://www.pli.edu/programs/climate-disclosures---a-deep-dive-into-the-secs-proposed-new-governance-strategy-and-risk-disclosures?t=live&tCode=CNS2_ATL01&utm_source=ATL01&utm_medium=DISPLAY&utm_campaign=CNS2). For another overview of the SEC’s proposed changes, you can access PLI’s previous one-hour program, [Climate Change – The SEC’s Proposed New Disclosures](https://www.pli.edu/programs/climate-change--the-secs-proposed-new-disclosures?t=ondemand&tCode=CNS2_ATL01&utm_source=ATL01&utm_medium=DISPLAY&utm_campaign=CNS2), on-demand.

# Latham Increases Its Partner Bonus Pool To 15% To Keep Rainmakers Happy And Stave Off Lateral Moves
## Will other firms be able to afford to make similar changes to their partner bonus pools?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 27, 2024 at 2:14 PMMarch 27, 2024 at 1:14 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/latham-increases-its-partner-bonus-pool-to-15-to-keep-rainmakers-happy-and-stave-off-lateral-moves/&text=Latham%20Increases%20Its%20Partner%20Bonus%20Pool%20To%2015%%20To%20Keep%20Rainmakers%20Happy%20And%20Stave%20Off%20Lateral%20Moves)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/latham-increases-its-partner-bonus-pool-to-15-to-keep-rainmakers-happy-and-stave-off-lateral-moves/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/latham-increases-its-partner-bonus-pool-to-15-to-keep-rainmakers-happy-and-stave-off-lateral-moves/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As more and more Biglaw firms move toward black-box compensation systems for their partners, one elite firm is doing things a little differently. As Biglaw associates know all too well, the best way to keep a top-performer around is to offer big bonuses — and the same premise apparently works for partners.

Latham & Watkins — a firm that brought in $5,321,007,000 gross revenue in 2022, putting it at No. 2 in the Am Law 100 — seems to have increased its bonus pool for partners, growing its profits reserved for this purpose to 15%, while at the same time limiting the number of partners who actually receive these bonuses. For what it’s worth, other firms tend to reserve about 7 to 8% of profits for partner bonuses. Here are some additional details from the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2024/03/26/latham-watkins-grows-bonus-pool-with-15-of-profits-as-firms-seek-flexibility-to-reward-top-earners/):

Latham’s growing profit pool has allowed the firm to pay some of its highest-performing partners in the range of $12 million to $15 million, the people said. Between 2018 and 2022, the firm grew net income from $1.68 billion to $2.86 billion, according to ALM data, an increase of 14.1%. That growth, combined with how the firm is engineering bonuses, has enabled a hefty spread from highest- to lowest-paid partners. Not only has the firm succeeded in the lateral market in recent years as a result, but this success has also likely helped catalyze changes at other firms with vestiges of a seniority-based lockstep system.

Rather than changing their share point system, as other firms have done, Latham has gradually shifted its profit reserves to allocate more money for partner bonuses. These increased bonuses are a way to pay partners what they — and perhaps more importantly, other rival firms eager to poach them — perceive to be their fair market value.

“The wider partnership is paying a little bit of money to competitively compensate the firm’s top people,” New York-based recruiter Mike Parrillo told Am Law — and in Latham’s favor, it seems to be working.

[Latham & Watkins Grows Bonus Pool With 15% of Profits, as Firms Seek Flexibility to Reward Top Earners](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2024/03/26/latham-watkins-grows-bonus-pool-with-15-of-profits-as-firms-seek-flexibility-to-reward-top-earners/) [American Lawyer]

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) and [Threads](https://www.threads.net/@stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).
